channel.title: Koobface Worm issue
channel.description: Well, the other day my mom was browsing Facebook when she clicked a link that her friend has posted. Well the link redirected her to a video which required her to download an updated adobe flash player. Well she attempted to update it, and the 'video' downloaded about 10 virus's one of them being the Koobface virus, which our virus protection didn't catch because the version downloaded was so new. So for the past 3 days or so, I have been trying to get this thing off her computer. It has completely rendered it useless. I have done everything from removing the process file (freddy58.exe) to downloading and running 4 different virus scanners. This thing is annoying, and extremely good at hiding. I'm not sure what else to do, and I can't find anything else because of 2 things. First, this thing makes it impossible to search for things by redirecting you to an ad site on everything. And the second is that my computer is broken (overheating issues). So I'm posting here hoping that someone has either had experiences with this and removed it, or can search and find something.

item.title: Koobface Worm issue
item.dc:creator: @Jamie1200 Jamie1200
item.description:
@Jamie1200 wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:7, topic:296456”][quote author=Lin link=topic=392456.msg2924283#msg2924283 date=1250918510]
I’d recommend getting some sort of anti-virus software and scanning in safe mode. Once it’s found, even if the anti-virus software can’t delete it, you can manually. Also check msconfig.exe.
[/quote]
From what i’ve heard, booting down with a virus is VERY dangerous.[/quote]
Yep VERY.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: 24-08-2009, 20:50:16[/size][hr][quote=“m.dog311, post:13, topic:296456”]I got it fixed, there’s not an anti-virus out there that seems to work. Eventually reinstallled windows and what not.[/quote]
Why Didnt YOu Just Delete it out of the registry?

Read full topic

item.title: Koobface Worm issue
item.dc:creator: @TabbyKiller TabbyKiller
item.description:
@TabbyKiller wrote:

Koobface is a worm that recently made headlines as it spread through Facebook and infected the PCs of many unsuspecting members of the popular social networking site. Koobface tricks a person into downloading its installation file, then redirects search engine traffic to a site called find-www.net. Facebook has been working on cleaning out their computer systems, and posted some advice for dealing with a Koobface infection.

Koobface spread through Facebook by using social engineering tricks. Victims see a link that appears to lead to a video of themselves. When the victim clicks the link, they are asked to upgrade their Flash player in order to watch the video. Instead of downloading the Flash player update, the Koobface worm installs itself.

Once Koobface has infected a PC, it hijacks search engine traffic and diverts it to a site called find-www.net. If a person with an infected computer tries to do a Google or Yahoo! search, they may end up at this illegitimate search engine instead.

Facebook posted a notice regarding the Koobface worm on their security page. They suggest that a person whose PC has been infected use an up-to-date virus scanner, and then reset their Facebook password. Some of the free online virus scanners suggested are Kaspersky, Symantec, McAfee and Microsoft Live OneCare.


http://www.kaspersky.com/virusscanner
http://security.symantec.com/
http://us.mcafee.com/root/mfs/scan.asp?affid=56
http://onecare.live.com/site/en-us/default.htm

Im guessing those are your Best Options[br][br][size=1]Posted on: August 22, 2009, 06:01:47 pm[/size][hr]http://www.antispyware.com/glossary_details.php?ID=134358
Im not sure if you could trust this site though but it seems pretty good. Except for the Download

Read full topic

item.title: Koobface Worm issue
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

I once downloaded a ‘flash player’ from a site, i later realised that it was infact not a flash player, and that it was a virus, which literally made it so whatever i type in google, it somehow comes up with some sort of porn site.
Honest, i typed in runescape, and it redirected me from runescape.com to some porn site.
It was pretty sick.

That resulted in restoring my pc to factory settings, thus losing all my data, and everything.

But that was about 4 years ago, i was stupid.

Read full topic

item.title: Koobface Worm issue
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:8, topic:296456”][quote author=Frell link=topic=392456.msg2924288#msg2924288 date=1250918630]

I’d recommend getting some sort of anti-virus software and scanning in safe mode. Once it’s found, even if the anti-virus software can’t delete it, you can manually. Also check msconfig.exe.

From what i’ve heard, booting down with a virus is VERY dangerous.
[/quote]When you boot in safe mode, nothing starts up on start-up except what’s necessary.

Or, I might’ve read that wrong. Booting down as in shutting down? Yea, I guess it can be, but it’s a risk :([/quote]
When you shut down your computer the virus can change your account password, multiply and embed itself much farther in your computer.

Read full topic

item.title: Koobface Worm issue
item.dc:creator: @Explisionist Explisionist
item.description:
@Explisionist wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:8, topic:296456”][quote author=Frell link=topic=392456.msg2924288#msg2924288 date=1250918630]

I’d recommend getting some sort of anti-virus software and scanning in safe mode. Once it’s found, even if the anti-virus software can’t delete it, you can manually. Also check msconfig.exe.

From what i’ve heard, booting down with a virus is VERY dangerous.
[/quote]When you boot in safe mode, nothing starts up on start-up except what’s necessary.

Or, I might’ve read that wrong. Booting down as in shutting down? Yea, I guess it can be, but it’s a risk :([/quote]

You don’t have to boot in safe mode, just disable your internet connection, and then scan your computer find it, if anti virus wont delete then you manually delete.

Read full topic

item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Hmm, If they wanted to hide it, they would make it polymorphic, with a 512 byte private key, and log it into a prtition of the ram.

But most virus makers won’t go into that much details on such a low level.

item.title: Koobface Worm issue
item.dc:creator: @Explisionist Explisionist
item.description:
@Explisionist wrote:

The Virus is using a backdoor accessory, disable your internet connection, find the file delete it then do what Lewk said, or do what he said first then disable your internet connection that way it can’t send data out or receive it.

Read full topic

item.title: Koobface Worm issue
item.dc:creator: @P_I_M_P_3_D_Tut `Lewk_
item.description:
@P_I_M_P_3_D_Tut wrote:

I suggest you use Malware byte’s anti malware. It can be found at www.download.com
Make sure you update it before you use it.
Also get ZoneAlarm firewall. It has a built in program control feature, which lets you scroll through a list of programs and disable their rights and ect. First DL ZoneAlarm and Disable the program. Then run Malware bytes and scan your computer.

Read full topic
